claim: Months are based on the solar cycle.

supporting.text: The Gregorian calendar, the most widely used civil calendar, aligns months with the solar year to keep seasons consistent over time.

attacks.text: The Gregorian calendar, the most widely used civil calendar, aligns months with the solar year to keep seasons consistent over time.
Many traditional calendars (e.g., lunar or lunisolar) do not align months with the solar cycle, showing months can exist independently of solar cycles.
The Gregorian calendar's solar alignment is a modern adaptation; historically, months were often lunar-based, proving their original independence from solar cycles.
Even the Gregorian calendar requires leap years and month-length adjustments, indicating imperfect alignment with the solar cycle.
Leap years and adjustments are minor corrections, not evidence against the fundamental solar alignment of months in the Gregorian system.

supporting.text: Many traditional calendars, such as the ancient Egyptian and Julian calendars, were designed to approximate the solar cycle through their month divisions.

attacks.text: Many traditional calendars, such as the ancient Egyptian and Julian calendars, were designed to approximate the solar cycle through their month divisions.
The Gregorian calendar, the most widely used calendar today, does not align its months with the solar cycle but rather uses arbitrary month lengths.
The Gregorian calendar still maintains a rough alignment with the solar year through leap years, even if individual months are not solar-based.
Lunar calendars, such as the Islamic calendar, are based on the moon's cycles and have no relation to the solar cycle, contradicting the universality of solar-based months.
Lunar calendars are often used for religious purposes and do not represent the majority of global timekeeping systems, which are solar or lunisolar.

supporting.text: Months are primarily based on lunar cycles (approximately 29.5 days), not the solar cycle, as seen in lunar calendars like the Islamic Hijri calendar.

attacks.text: Months are primarily based on lunar cycles (approximately 29.5 days), not the solar cycle, as seen in lunar calendars like the Islamic Hijri calendar.
Many modern calendars, such as the Gregorian calendar, are solar-based and define months as arbitrary divisions of the solar year, not tied to lunar cycles.
Even in solar-based calendars, the concept of months historically originated from lunar cycles, and their lengths were later adjusted for solar alignment.
The term 'month' itself is derived from 'moon,' indicating its original lunar connection, regardless of later solar adaptations.
Some cultures, like the Chinese, use lunisolar calendars where months are lunar but periodically adjusted to stay in sync with the solar year.

supporting.text: The length of months in the Gregorian calendar (28-31 days) does not directly correspond to any consistent fraction of the solar year (365.24 days).

attacks.text: The length of months in the Gregorian calendar (28-31 days) does not directly correspond to any consistent fraction of the solar year (365.24 days).
Months are historically based on lunar cycles (~29.5 days), not the solar cycle, which is why their lengths vary.
The Gregorian calendar was designed to approximate the solar year by adjusting month lengths and adding leap years, aligning months indirectly with the solar cycle.
Even with adjustments, months remain arbitrary divisions of the solar year, lacking a direct astronomical basis.
